title: Chronic Neck Pain in an Office Administrator: The Case of Mr. Ajay Kumar
clinical_history: Mr. Ajay Kumar is a 43-year-old office administrator who presents with a 5-month history of insidious onset neck pain. He has been working from home since the pandemic, often spending long hours at a poorly set-up workstation. The pain is described as a deep, aching discomfort localized to the lower cervical spine and right upper trapezius, sometimes radiating to the right shoulder. He reports morning stiffness lasting 30-40 minutes, which gradually improves as the day progresses. The pain intensifies through the workday, especially during prolonged screen time or when on calls, and is occasionally associated with mild headaches. He denies any trauma, numbness, or weakness in the upper limb. He reports that his symptoms are worse while driving and after stressful workdays. He tried over-the-counter paracetamol with mild, temporary relief. Sleep quality has declined due to discomfort with certain pillow positions.

nprs.affected_area: lower cervical spine (C5-C7), right upper trapezius

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged desk work (>45 minutes), looking down at mobile devices, driving for longer than 20 minutes, poor postural habits, stressful work situations.
picture: [insert image highlighting posterior neck (midline and right upper trapezius) and referred right shoulder area]
easing_factors: Taking short breaks from work, gentle neck stretches, warm compress at the end of the day, lying supine with a rolled towel under the neck.
past_history: No significant past musculoskeletal injuries. Occasional non-specific low back pain resolved with rest.
medical_history: Non-diabetic, non-hypertensive, BMI 28. Occasional mild gastritis.
medications: Paracetamol 500mg as needed (up to twice/day). No regular prescription medications.
personal_history: Non-smoker, occasional social drinker, married with two school-age children. Reports high job stress since pandemic work-from-home transition. Limited physical activity, rarely exercises.
imaging: None yet performed. If persistent, may consider cervical spine X-ray/MRI.
